description: From French mélodrame, the second element refashioned by analogy with drama; ultimately from Ancient Greek μέλος (mélos, “limb”, “member”, “song”, “tune”, “melody”) + δρᾶμα (drâma, “deed”, “theatrical act”). Compare melodrame. Cognate to German Melodram and Spanish melodrama.

nouns.description: melodrama (countable and uncountable, plural melodramas or melodramata)

entries.meaning: (archaic, uncountable) A kind of drama having a musical accompaniment to intensify the effect of certain scenes.

(countable) A drama abounding in romantic sentiment and agonizing situations, with a musical accompaniment only in parts which are especially thrilling or pathetic. In opera, a passage in which the orchestra plays a somewhat descriptive accompaniment, while the actor speaks
examples: the melodrama in the grave digging scene of Beethoven's "Fidelio".

entries.meaning: (uncountable, figuratively, colloquial) Any situation or action which is blown out of proportion.
